# History of the Great Wall of China

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Map_of_the_Great_Wall_of_China.jpg/450px-
Map_of_the_Great_Wall_of_China.jpg)](/wiki/File:Map_of_the_Great_Wall_of_China.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Map_of_the_Great_Wall_of_China.jpg "Enlarge")

Course of the Wall throughout history

The **history of the[Great Wall of China](/wiki/Great_Wall_of_China "Great
Wall of China")** began when fortifications built by various
[states](/wiki/Ancient_Chinese_states "Ancient Chinese states") during the
[Spring and Autumn](/wiki/Spring_and_Autumn_period "Spring and Autumn period")
(771–476 BC)[1] and [Warring States](/wiki/Warring_States_period "Warring
States period") periods (475–221 BC) were connected by the first emperor of
China, [Qin Shi Huang](/wiki/Qin_Shi_Huang "Qin Shi Huang"), to protect his
newly founded [Qin dynasty](/wiki/Qin_dynasty "Qin dynasty") (221–206 BC)
against incursions by [nomads from Inner Asia](/wiki/Eurasian_nomads "Eurasian
nomads"). The walls were built of rammed earth, constructed using forced
labour, and by 212 BC ran from [Gansu](/wiki/Gansu "Gansu") to the coast of
southern [Manchuria](/wiki/Manchuria "Manchuria").

Later dynasties adopted different policies towards northern frontier defense.
The [Han](/wiki/Han_dynasty "Han dynasty") (202 BC – 220 AD), the [Northern
Qi](/wiki/Northern_Qi "Northern Qi") (550–574), the [Sui](/wiki/Sui_dynasty
"Sui dynasty") (589–618), and particularly the [Ming](/wiki/Ming_dynasty "Ming
dynasty") (1369–1644) were among those that rebuilt, re-manned, and expanded
the Walls, although they rarely followed Qin's routes. The Han extended the
fortifications furthest to the west, the Qi built about 1,600 kilometres (990
mi) of new walls, while the Sui mobilised over a million men in their wall-
building efforts. Conversely, the [Tang](/wiki/Tang_dynasty "Tang dynasty")
(618–907), the [Song](/wiki/Song_dynasty "Song dynasty") (960–1279), the
[Yuan](/wiki/Yuan_dynasty "Yuan dynasty") (1271–1368), and the
[Qing](/wiki/Qing_dynasty "Qing dynasty") (1644–1911) mostly did not build
frontier walls, instead opting for other solutions to the Inner Asian threat
like military campaigning and diplomacy.

Although a useful deterrent against raids, at several points throughout its
history the Great Wall failed to stop enemies, including in 1644 when the
[Manchu](/wiki/Manchu "Manchu") Qing marched through the gates of [Shanhai
Pass](/wiki/Shanhai_Pass "Shanhai Pass") and replaced the most ardent of the
wall-building dynasties, the Ming, as rulers of China.

The Great Wall of China visible today largely dates from the Ming dynasty, as
they rebuilt much of the wall in stone and brick, often extending its line
through challenging terrain.[2] Some sections remain in relatively good
condition or have been renovated, while others have been damaged or destroyed
for ideological reasons,[3] deconstructed for their building materials,[3] or
lost due to the ravages of time.[4] For long an object of fascination for
foreigners, the wall is now a revered national symbol and a popular tourist
destination.[5]

## Geographical
considerations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_Great_Wall_of_China&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Geographical considerations")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Gobi_desert_map.png/300px-
Gobi_desert_map.png)](/wiki/File:Gobi_desert_map.png)

[](/wiki/File:Gobi_desert_map.png "Enlarge")

Topographical map of China's northern frontier area, with modern political
boundaries. [Manchuria](/wiki/Manchuria "Manchuria"), unmarked, is to the east
of [Inner Mongolia](/wiki/Inner_Mongolia "Inner Mongolia").

The conflict between the Chinese and the nomads, from which the need for the
Great Wall arose, stemmed from differences in geography. The 15"
[isohyet](/wiki/Isohyet "Isohyet") marks the extent of settled agriculture,
dividing the fertile fields of China to the south and the [semi-
arid](/wiki/Semi-arid_climate "Semi-arid climate") grasslands of Inner Asia to
the north.[6] The climates and the topography of the two regions led to
distinct modes of societal development.[7]

According to the model by sinologist [Karl August
Wittfogel](/wiki/Karl_August_Wittfogel "Karl August Wittfogel"), the
[loess](/wiki/Loess "Loess") soils of [Shaanxi](/wiki/Shaanxi "Shaanxi") made
it possible for the Chinese to develop irrigated agriculture early on.
Although this allowed them to expand into the lower reaches of the [Yellow
River](/wiki/Yellow_River "Yellow River") valley,[8] such extensive waterworks
on an ever-increasing scale required collective labour, something that could
only be managed by some form of bureaucracy.[9] Thus the [scholar-
bureaucrats](/wiki/Scholar-official "Scholar-official") came to the fore to
keep track of the income and expenses of the [granaries](/wiki/Granary
"Granary"). [Walled cities](/wiki/Chinese_city_wall "Chinese city wall") grew
up around the granaries for reasons of defence along with ease of
administration; they kept invaders out and ensured that citizens remained
within.[10] These cities combined to become [feudal
states](/wiki/Ancient_Chinese_states "Ancient Chinese states"), which
eventually united to become an empire. Likewise, according to this model,
walls not only enveloped cities as time went by, but also lined the borders of
the feudal states and eventually the whole Chinese empire to provide
protection against raids from the agrarian northern steppes.[9]

The steppe societies of Inner Asia, whose climate favoured a
[pastoral](/wiki/Pastoral "Pastoral") economy, stood in stark contrast to the
Chinese mode of development. As animal herds are migratory by nature,
communities could not afford to be stationary and therefore evolved as nomads.
According to the influential Mongolist [Owen Lattimore](/wiki/Owen_Lattimore
"Owen Lattimore") this lifestyle proved to be incompatible with the Chinese
economic model.[11] As the steppe population grew, pastoral agriculture alone
could not support the population, and tribal alliances needed to be maintained
by material rewards. For these needs, the nomads had to turn to the settled
societies to get grains, metal tools, and luxury goods, which they could not
produce by themselves. If denied trade by the settled peoples, the nomads
would resort to raiding or even conquest.[12]

Potential nomadic incursion from three main areas of Inner Asia caused concern
to northern China: [Mongolia](/wiki/Mongolia "Mongolia") to the north,
[Manchuria](/wiki/Manchuria "Manchuria") to the northeast, and
[Xinjiang](/wiki/Xinjiang "Xinjiang") to the northwest.[13] Of the three,
China's chief concern since the earliest times had been Mongolia – the home of
many of the country's fiercest enemies including the [Xiongnu](/wiki/Xiongnu
"Xiongnu"), the [Xianbei](/wiki/Xianbei "Xianbei"), the
[Khitans](/wiki/Khitans "Khitans"), and the [Mongols](/wiki/Mongols
"Mongols"). The [Gobi Desert](/wiki/Gobi_Desert "Gobi Desert"), which accounts
for two-thirds of Mongolia's area, divided the main northern and southern
grazing lands and pushed the pastoral nomads to the fringes of the steppe. On
the southern side ([Inner Mongolia](/wiki/Inner_Mongolia "Inner Mongolia")),
this pressure brought the nomads into contact with China.[14]

For the most part, barring intermittent passes and valleys (the major one
being the corridor through [Zhangjiakou](/wiki/Zhangjiakou "Zhangjiakou") and
the [Juyong Pass](/wiki/Juyong_Pass "Juyong Pass")), the [North China
Plain](/wiki/North_China_Plain "North China Plain") remained shielded from the
Mongolian steppe by the [Yin Mountains](/wiki/Yin_Mountains "Yin
Mountains").[15] However, if this defence were breached, China's flat terrain
offered no protection to the cities on the plain, including the imperial
capitals of [Beijing](/wiki/Beijing "Beijing"), [Kaifeng](/wiki/Kaifeng
"Kaifeng"), and [Luoyang](/wiki/Luoyang "Luoyang").[16] Heading west along the
Yin Mountains, the range ends where the Yellow River circles northwards
upstream in the area known as the [Ordos Loop](/wiki/Ordos_Loop "Ordos
Loop")—technically part of the steppe, but capable of irrigated agriculture.
Although the Yellow River formed a theoretical natural boundary with the
north, such a border so far into the steppe was difficult to maintain. The
lands south of the Yellow River—the [Hetao](/wiki/Hetao "Hetao"), the [Ordos
Desert](/wiki/Ordos_Desert "Ordos Desert"), and the [Loess
Plateau](/wiki/Loess_Plateau "Loess Plateau")—provided no natural barriers on
the approach to the [Wei River](/wiki/Wei_River "Wei River") valley, the oft-
called cradle of Chinese civilization where the ancient capital
[Xi'an](/wiki/Xi%27an "Xi'an") lay. As such, control of the Ordos remained
extremely important for the rulers of China: not only for potential influence
over the steppe, but also for the security of [China
proper](/wiki/China_proper "China proper"). The region's strategic importance
combined with its untenability led many dynasties to place their first walls
here.[17]

Although Manchuria is home to the agricultural lands of the [Liao
River](/wiki/Liao_River "Liao River") valley, its location beyond the northern
mountains relegated it to the relative periphery of Chinese concern. When
Chinese state control became weak, at various points in history Manchuria fell
under the control of the forest peoples of the area, including the
[Jurchens](/wiki/Jurchens "Jurchens") and the [Manchus](/wiki/Manchus
"Manchus"). The most crucial route that links Manchuria and the North China
Plain is a narrow coastal strip of land, wedged between the [Bohai
Sea](/wiki/Bohai_Sea "Bohai Sea") and the [Yan Mountains](/wiki/Yan_Mountains
"Yan Mountains"), called the [Shanhai Pass](/wiki/Shanhai_Pass "Shanhai Pass")
(literally the "mountain and sea pass").[18] The pass gained much importance
during the later dynasties, when the capital was set in Beijing, a mere 300
kilometres (190 miles) away. In addition to the Shanhai Pass, a handful of
mountain passes also provide access from Manchuria into China through the [Yan
Mountains](/wiki/Yan_Mountains "Yan Mountains"), chief among them the
[Gubeikou](/wiki/Gubeikou "Gubeikou") and
[Xifengkou](/w/index.php?title=Xifengkou&action=edit&redlink=1 "Xifengkou
\(page does not exist\)") ([Chinese](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters
"Traditional Chinese characters"): 喜峰口).[19]

Xinjiang, considered part of the [Turkestan](/wiki/Turkestan "Turkestan")
region, consists of an amalgamation of deserts, oases, and dry steppe barely
suitable for agriculture.[18] When influence from the steppe powers of
Mongolia waned, the various [Central Asian](/wiki/Central_Asia "Central Asia")
oasis kingdoms and nomadic clans like the [Göktürks](/wiki/G%C3%B6kt%C3%BCrks
"Göktürks") and [Uyghurs](/wiki/Uyghurs "Uyghurs") were able to form their own
states and confederations that threatened China at times. China proper is
connected to this area by the [Hexi Corridor](/wiki/Hexi_Corridor "Hexi
Corridor"), a narrow string of oases bounded by the Gobi Desert to the north
and the high [Tibetan Plateau](/wiki/Tibetan_Plateau "Tibetan Plateau") to the
south.[20] In addition to considerations of frontier defence, the Hexi
Corridor also formed an important part of the [Silk Road](/wiki/Silk_Road
"Silk Road") trade route. Thus it was also in China's economic interest to
control this stretch of land, and hence the Great Wall's western terminus is
in this corridor—the [Yumen Pass](/wiki/Yumen_Pass "Yumen Pass") during Han
times and the [Jiayu Pass](/wiki/Jiayu_Pass "Jiayu Pass") during the Ming
dynasty and thereafter.[21]

## Pre-imperial China (7th century–221
BC)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_Great_Wall_of_China&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Pre-imperial China \(7th century–221 BC\)")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Great_wall_of_qi_2008_07_14.jpg/220px-
Great_wall_of_qi_2008_07_14.jpg)](/wiki/File:Great_wall_of_qi_2008_07_14.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Great_wall_of_qi_2008_07_14.jpg "Enlarge")

Remnants of the [Great Wall of Qi](/wiki/Great_Wall_of_Qi "Great Wall of Qi")
on Dafeng Mountain, Changqing District, [Jinan](/wiki/Jinan "Jinan"), which
was once part of the ancient [State of Qi](/wiki/Qi_\(state\) "Qi \(state\)")
during the [Warring States Period](/wiki/Warring_States_Period "Warring States
Period").

One of the first mentions of a wall built against northern invaders is found
in a poem, dated from the seventh century BC, recorded in the _[Classic of
Poetry](/wiki/Classic_of_Poetry "Classic of Poetry")_. The poem tells of a
king, now identified as [King Xuan](/wiki/King_Xuan_of_Zhou "King Xuan of
Zhou") (r. 827 – 782 BC) of the [Western Zhou
dynasty](/wiki/Western_Zhou_dynasty "Western Zhou dynasty") (1046 – 771 BC),
who commanded General Nan Zhong (南仲) to build a wall in the northern regions
to fend off the [Xianyun](/wiki/Xianyun "Xianyun").[22] The Xianyun, whose
base of power was in the Ordos region, were regarded as part of the
charioteering [Rong](/wiki/Xirong_\(people\) "Xirong \(people\)") tribes,[23]
and their attacks aimed at the early Zhou capital region of
[Haojing](/wiki/Haojing "Haojing") were probably the reason for King Xuan's
response.[22] Nan Zhong's campaign was recorded as a great victory. However,
only a few years later in 771 BC another branch of the Rong people, the
[Quanrong](/wiki/Quanrong "Quanrong"), responded to a summons by the renegade
[Marquess of Shen](/wiki/Marquess_of_Shen "Marquess of Shen") by over-running
the Zhou defences and laying waste to the capital. The cataclysmic event
killed King Xuan's successor [King You](/wiki/King_You_of_Zhou "King You of
Zhou") (795–771 BC), forced the court to move the capital east to Chengzhou
(成周, later known as [Luoyang](/wiki/Luoyang "Luoyang")) a year later, and thus
ushered in the [Eastern Zhou dynasty](/wiki/Eastern_Zhou_dynasty "Eastern Zhou
dynasty") (770–256 BC). Most importantly, the fall of Western Zhou
redistributed power to the states that had acknowledged Zhou's nominal
rulership. The rule of the Eastern Zhou dynasty was marked by bloody
interstate anarchy. With smaller states being annexed and larger states waging
constant war upon one another, many rulers came to feel the need to erect
walls to protect their borders. Of the earliest textual reference to such a
wall was the [State of Chu](/wiki/State_of_Chu "State of Chu")'s wall of 656
BC, 1,400 metres (4,600 feet) of which were excavated in southern
[Henan](/wiki/Henan "Henan") province in the modern era. However the Chu
border fortifications consisted of many individual mountain fortresses; they
do not constitute to a lengthy, single wall. The [State of
Qi](/wiki/State_of_Qi "State of Qi") also had fortified borders up by the 7th
century BC, and the extant portions in [Shandong](/wiki/Shandong "Shandong")
province had been christened the [Great Wall of Qi](/wiki/Great_Wall_of_Qi
"Great Wall of Qi"). The [State of Wei](/wiki/State_of_Wei "State of Wei")
built two walls, the western one completed in 361 BC and the eastern in 356
BC, with the extant western wall found in [Hancheng](/wiki/Hancheng
"Hancheng"), [Shaanxi](/wiki/Shaanxi "Shaanxi").[24] Even non-Chinese peoples
built walls, such as the [Di](/wiki/Beidi "Beidi") state of
[Zhongshan](/wiki/Zhongshan_\(state\) "Zhongshan \(state\)") and the
[Yiqu](/wiki/Yiqu "Yiqu") Rong, whose walls were intended to defend against
the [State of Qin](/wiki/State_of_Qin "State of Qin").[25]

Of these walls, those of the northern states [Yan](/wiki/Yan_\(state\) "Yan
\(state\)"), [Zhao](/wiki/Zhao_\(state\) "Zhao \(state\)"), and Qin were
connected by Qin Shi Huang when he united the Chinese states in 221 BC.[25]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/GreatWallChina1.png/300px-
GreatWallChina1.png)](/wiki/File:GreatWallChina1.png)

[](/wiki/File:GreatWallChina1.png "Enlarge")

Map of the Warring States and their frontier walls

The State of Yan, the easternmost of the three northern states, began to erect
walls after the general [Qin Kai](/wiki/Qin_Kai_\(general\) "Qin Kai
\(general\)") drove the [Donghu](/wiki/Donghu_people "Donghu people") people
back "a thousand _[li](/wiki/Li_\(unit\) "Li \(unit\)")_ " during the reign of
[King Zhao](/w/index.php?title=King_Zhao_of_Yan&action=edit&redlink=1 "King
Zhao of Yan \(page does not exist\)") (燕昭王; r. 311–279 BC).[26] The Yan wall
stretched from the [Liaodong peninsula](/wiki/Liaodong_peninsula "Liaodong
peninsula"), through [Chifeng](/wiki/Chifeng "Chifeng"), and into northern
[Hebei](/wiki/Hebei "Hebei"), possibly bringing its western terminus near the
Zhao walls.[27] Another Yan wall was erected to the south to defend against
the Zhao; it was southwest of present-day Beijing and ran parallel to the
[Juma River](/wiki/Juma_River_\(China\) "Juma River \(China\)") for several
dozen miles.[28]

The Zhao walls to the north were built under [King Wuling of
Zhao](/wiki/King_Wuling_of_Zhao "King Wuling of Zhao") (r. 325–299 BC), whose
groundbreaking introduction of nomadic cavalry into his army reshaped Chinese
warfare and gave Zhao an initial advantage over his opponents. He attacked the
[Xiongnu](/wiki/Xiongnu "Xiongnu") tribes of Linhu (林胡) and Loufan (樓煩) to the
north, then waged war on the state of Zhongshan until it was annexed in 296
BC. In the process, he constructed the northernmost fortified frontier deep in
nomadic territory.[29] The Zhao walls were dated in the 1960s to be from King
Wuling's reign:[30] a southern long wall in northern [Henan](/wiki/Henan
"Henan") encompassing the [Yanmen Pass](/wiki/Yanmen_Pass "Yanmen Pass");[31]
a second line of barricades encircling the [Ordos Loop](/wiki/Ordos_Loop
"Ordos Loop"), extending from [Zhangjiakou](/wiki/Zhangjiakou "Zhangjiakou")
in the east to the ancient fortress of Gaoque (高闕) in the [Urad Front
Banner](/wiki/Urad_Front_Banner "Urad Front Banner"); and a third,
northernmost line along the southern slopes of the [Yin
Mountains](/wiki/Yin_Mountains "Yin Mountains"), extending from
[Qinghe](/wiki/Qinghe_County,_Hebei "Qinghe County, Hebei") in the east,
passing north of [Hohhot](/wiki/Hohhot "Hohhot"), and into
[Baotou](/wiki/Baotou "Baotou").[32]

Qin was originally a state on the western fringe of the Chinese political
sphere, but it grew into a formidable power in the later parts of the [Warring
States period](/wiki/Warring_States_period "Warring States period") when it
aggressively expanded in all directions. In the north, the state of Wei and
the Yiqu built walls to protect themselves from Qin aggression, but were still
unable to stop Qin from eating into their territories. The Qin reformist
[Shang Yang](/wiki/Shang_Yang "Shang Yang") forced the Wei out of their walled
area west of the Yellow River in 340 BC, and [King Huiwen of
Qin](/wiki/King_Huiwen_of_Qin "King Huiwen of Qin") (r. 338–311 BC) took 25
Yiqu forts in a northern offensive.[33] When King Huiwen died, his widow the
[Queen Dowager Xuan](/wiki/Queen_Dowager_Xuan "Queen Dowager Xuan") acted as
regent because the succeeding sons were deemed too young to govern. During the
reign of [King Zhaoxiang](/wiki/King_Zhaoxiang_of_Qin "King Zhaoxiang of Qin")
(r. 306–251 BC), the queen dowager apparently entered illicit relations with
the Yiqu king and gave birth to two of his sons, but later tricked and killed
the Yiqu king. Following that coup, the Qin army marched into Yiqu territory
at the queen dowager's orders; the Qin annihilated the Yiqu remnants and thus
came to possess the Ordos region.[34] At this point the Qin built a wall
around their new territories to defend against the true nomads even further
north, incorporating the Wei walls. As a result, an estimated total of 1,775
kilometres (1,103 mi) of Qin walls (including spurts) extended from southern
[Gansu](/wiki/Gansu "Gansu") to the bank of the Yellow River in the [Jungar
Banner](/wiki/Jungar_Banner "Jungar Banner"), close to the border with Zhao at
the time.[35]

The walls, known as _Changcheng_ (長城) – literally "long walls", but often
translated as "Great Wall"[36] – were mostly constructed of [tamped
earth](/wiki/Tamped_earth "Tamped earth"), with some parts built with stones.
Where natural barriers like ravines and rivers sufficed for defence, the walls
were erected sparingly, but long fortified lines were laid where such
advantageous terrains did not exist. Often in addition to the wall, the
defensive system included garrisons and [beacon
towers](/wiki/Beacon#For_defensive_communications "Beacon") inside the wall,
and [watchtowers](/wiki/Watchtowers "Watchtowers") outside at regular
intervals.[37] In terms of defence, the walls were generally effective at
countering cavalry [shock tactics](/wiki/Shock_tactics "Shock tactics"),[38]
but there are doubts as to whether these early walls were actually defensive
in nature. Nicola Di Cosmo points out that the northern frontier walls were
built far to the north and included traditionally nomadic lands, and so rather
than being defensive, the walls indicate the northward expansions of the three
northern states and their desire to safeguard their recent territorial
acquisitions.[39] This theory is supported by the archeological discovery of
nomadic artifacts within the walls, suggesting the presence of pre-existing or
conquered barbarian societies.[40] It is entirely possible, as Western
scholars like di Cosmo and Lattimore suggest, that nomadic aggression against
the Chinese in the coming centuries was partly caused by Chinese expansionism
during this period.[41]

## Qin dynasty (221–206
BC)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_Great_Wall_of_China&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Qin dynasty \(221–206 BC\)")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/GreatWallofQinDynasty.png/220px-
GreatWallofQinDynasty.png)](/wiki/File:GreatWallofQinDynasty.png)

[](/wiki/File:GreatWallofQinDynasty.png "Enlarge")

Qin dynasty frontier walls

In 221 BC, the state of Qin completed its [conquest over the other Warring
States](/wiki/Qin%27s_wars_of_unification "Qin's wars of unification") and
united China under [Qin Shi Huang](/wiki/Qin_Shi_Huang "Qin Shi Huang"), the
first [emperor of China](/wiki/Emperor_of_China "Emperor of China"). These
conquests, combined with the [Legalist](/wiki/Legalism_\(Chinese_philosophy\)
"Legalism \(Chinese philosophy\)") reforms started by Shang Yang in the 4th
century BC, transformed China from a loose confederation of [feudal
states](/wiki/Examples_of_feudalism#China "Examples of feudalism") to an
authoritarian [empire](/wiki/Empire "Empire"). With the transformation, Qin
became able to command a far greater assembly of labourers to be used in
public works than the prior feudal kingdoms.[42] Also, once unification was
achieved, Qin found itself in possession of a large professional army with no
more internal enemies to fight and thus had to find a new use for them.[43]
Soon after the conquests, in the year 215 BC, the emperor sent the famed
general [Meng Tian](/wiki/Meng_Tian "Meng Tian") to the Ordos region to drive
out the [Xiongnu](/wiki/Xiongnu "Xiongnu") nomads settled there, who had risen
from beyond the fallen marginal states along the northern frontier. [Qin's
campaign against the Xiongnu](/wiki/Qin%27s_campaign_against_the_Xiongnu
"Qin's campaign against the Xiongnu") was preemptive in nature, since there
was no pressing nomadic menace to be faced at the time; its aim was to annexe
the ambiguous territories of the Ordos and to clearly define the Qin's
northern borders.[44] Once the Xiongnu were chased away, Meng Tian introduced
30,000 settler families to colonize the newly conquered territories.[45]

Wall configurations were changed to reflect the new borders under the Qin.
General Meng Tian erected walls beyond the northern loop of the Yellow River,
effectively linking the border walls of Qin, Zhao, and Yan. Concurrent to the
building of the frontier wall was the destruction of the walls within China
that used to divide one warring state from another—contrary to the outer
walls, which were built to stabilize the newly united China, the inner walls
threatened the unity of the empire. In the following year, 214 BC, Qin Shi
Huang ordered new fortifications to be built along the Yellow River to the
west of the Ordos while work continued in the north. This work was completed
probably by 212 BC, signalled by Qin Shi Huang's imperial tour of inspection
and the construction of the Direct Road (直道) connecting the capital
[Xianyang](/wiki/Xianyang "Xianyang") with the Ordos.[46] The result was a
series of long walls running from Gansu to the seacoast in Manchuria.[47]

Details of the construction were not found in the [official
histories](/wiki/Official_history "Official history"),[48] but it could be
inferred that the construction conditions were made especially difficult by
the long stretches of mountains and semi-desert that the Great Wall traversed,
the sparse populations of these areas, and the frigid winter climate. Although
the walls were rammed earth, so the bulk of the building material could be
found _in situ_ , transportation of additional supplies and labour remained
difficult for the reasons named above. The sinologist [Derk
Bodde](/wiki/Derk_Bodde "Derk Bodde") posits in _[The Cambridge History of
China](/wiki/The_Cambridge_History_of_China "The Cambridge History of China")_
that "for every man whom Meng Tian could put to work at the scene of actual
construction, dozens must have been needed to build approaching roads and to
transport supplies."[49] This is supported by the Han dynasty statesman [Zhufu
Yan](/wiki/Zhufu_Yan "Zhufu Yan")'s description of Qin Shi Huang's Ordos
project in 128 BC:

> ... the land was brackish and arid, crops could not be grown on them. ... At
> the time, the young men being drafted were forced to haul boats and barges
> loaded with baggage trains upstream to sustain a steady supply of food and
> fodder to the front. ... Commencing at the departure point a man and his
> animal could carry thirty _zhong_ (about 176 kilograms (388 lb)) of food
> supply, by the time they arrived at the destination, they merely delivered
> one _[dan](/wiki/Picul "Picul")_ (about 29 kilograms (64 lb)) of supply. ...
> When the populace had become tired and weary they started to dissipate and
> abscond. The orphans, the frail, the widowed and the seniors were
> desperately trying to escape from their appallingly derelict state and died
> on the wayside as they wandered away from their home. People started to
> revolt.[50]

The settlement of the north continued up to Qin Shi Huang's death in 210 BC,
upon which Meng Tian was ordered to commit suicide in a succession conspiracy.
Before killing himself, Meng Tian expressed regret for his walls: "Beginning
at Lintao and reaching to Liaodong, I built walls and dug moats for more than
ten thousand _li_ ; was it not inevitable that I broke the earth's veins along
the way? This then was my offense."[51]

Meng Tian's settlements in the north were abandoned, and the Xiongnu nomads
moved back into the Ordos Loop as the Qin empire became consumed by widespread
rebellion due to public discontent. Owen Lattimore concluded that the whole
project relied upon military power to enforce agriculture on a land more
suited for herding, resulting in "the anti-historical paradox of attempting
two mutually exclusive forms of development simultaneously" that was doomed to
fail.[45]

## Han dynasty (206 BC–220
AD)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_Great_Wall_of_China&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Han dynasty \(206 BC–220 AD\)")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/GreatWallChina2.png/220px-

In 202 BC, the former peasant [Liu Bang](/wiki/Liu_Bang "Liu Bang") emerged
victorious from the [Chu–Han Contention](/wiki/Chu%E2%80%93Han_Contention
"Chu–Han Contention") that followed the rebellion that toppled the Qin
dynasty, and proclaimed himself Emperor of the [Han dynasty](/wiki/Han_dynasty
"Han dynasty"), becoming known as Emperor Gaozu of Han (r. 202–195 BC) to
posterity. Unable to address the problem of the resurgent Xiongnu in the Ordos
region through military means, Emperor Gaozu was forced to appease the
Xiongnu. In exchange for peace, the Han offered tributes along with princesses
to marry off to the Xiongnu chiefs. These diplomatic marriages would become
known as _[heqin](/wiki/Heqin "Heqin")_ , and the terms specified that the
Great Wall (determined to be either the Warring States period Qin state
wall[52] or a short stretch of wall south of [Yanmen Pass](/wiki/Yanmen_Pass
"Yanmen Pass")[53]) was to serve as the line across which neither party would
venture.[54] In 162 BC, Gaozu's son [Emperor Wen](/wiki/Emperor_Wen_of_Han
"Emperor Wen of Han") clarified the agreement, suggesting the Xiongnu
_[chanyu](/wiki/Chanyu "Chanyu")_ held authority north of the Wall and the Han
emperor held authority south of it.[55] [Sima Qian](/wiki/Sima_Qian "Sima
Qian"), the author of the _[Records of the Grand
Historian](/wiki/Records_of_the_Grand_Historian "Records of the Grand
Historian")_ , describes the result of this agreement as one of peace and
friendship: "from the chanyu downwards, all the Xiongnu grew friendly with the
Han, coming and going along the Long Wall".[56] However, Chinese records show
that the Xiongnu often did not respect the agreement, as the Xiongnu cavalry
numbering up to 100,000 made several intrusions into Han territory despite the
intermarriage.[57]

To Chinese minds, the _heqin_ policy was humiliating and ran contrary to the
[Sinocentric](/wiki/Sinocentrism "Sinocentrism") world order like "a person
hanging upside down", as the statesman [Jia Yi](/wiki/Jia_Yi "Jia Yi") (d. 169
BC) puts it.[56] These sentiments manifested themselves in the Han court in
the form of the pro-war faction, who advocated the reversal of Han's policy of
appeasement. By the reign of [Emperor Wu](/wiki/Emperor_Wu_of_Han "Emperor Wu
of Han") (r. 141–87 BC), the Han felt comfortable enough to go to war with the
Xiongnu. After a botched attempt at luring the Xiongnu army into an ambush at
the [Battle of Mayi](/wiki/Battle_of_Mayi "Battle of Mayi") in 133 BC,[58] the
era of _heqin_ -style appeasement was broken and the [Han–Xiongnu
War](/wiki/Han%E2%80%93Xiongnu_War "Han–Xiongnu War") went into full
swing.[59]
