As the Han–Xiongnu War progressed in favour of the Han, the Wall became
maintained and extended beyond Qin lines. In 127 BC, General [Wei
Qing](/wiki/Wei_Qing "Wei Qing") invaded the much-contested Ordos region as
far as the Qin fortifications set up by Meng Tian. In this way, Wei Qing
reconquered the irrigable lands north of the Ordos and restored the spur of
defences protecting that territory from the steppe.[60] In addition to
rebuilding the walls, archeologists believe that the Han also erected
thousands of kilometres of walls from Hebei to Inner Mongolia during Emperor
Wu's reign.[61] The fortifications here include embankments, beacon stations,
and forts, all constructed with a combination of tamped-earth cores and stone
frontages.[62] From the Ordos Loop, the sporadic and non-continuous Han Great
Wall followed the northern edge of the Hexi Corridor through the cities of
[Wuwei](/wiki/Wuwei,_Gansu "Wuwei, Gansu"), [Zhangye](/wiki/Zhangye
"Zhangye"), and [Jiuquan](/wiki/Jiuquan "Jiuquan"), leading into the [Juyan
Lake Basin](/wiki/Juyan_Lake_Basin "Juyan Lake Basin"), and terminating in two
places: the [Yumen Pass](/wiki/Yumen_Pass "Yumen Pass") in the north, or the
[Yang Pass](/wiki/Yang_Pass "Yang Pass") to the south, both in the vicinity of
[Dunhuang](/wiki/Dunhuang "Dunhuang").[63] Yumen Pass was the most westerly of
all Han Chinese fortifications – further west than the western terminus of the
Ming Great Wall at [Jiayu Pass](/wiki/Jiayuguan_\(pass\) "Jiayuguan
\(pass\)"), about 460 kilometres (290 mi) to the east. The garrisons of the
watchtowers on the wall were supported by civilian farming and by military
agricultural colonies known as _[tuntian](/wiki/Tuntian "Tuntian")_. Behind
this line of fortifications, the Han government was able to maintain its
settlements and its communications to the [Western
Regions](/wiki/Western_Regions "Western Regions") in central Asia, generally
secure from attacks from the north.[64]

The campaigns against the Xiongnu and other nomadic peoples of the west
exhausted the imperial treasury, and the expansionist policies were reverted
in favour of peace under Emperor Wu's successors. The peace was largely
respected even when the Han throne was usurped by the minister [Wang
Mang](/wiki/Wang_Mang "Wang Mang") in 9 AD, beginning a brief 15-year
interregnum known as the [Xin dynasty](/wiki/Xin_dynasty "Xin dynasty")
(9–23). Despite high tensions between the Xin and the Xiongnu resulting in the
deployment of 300,000 men on the Great Wall, no major fighting broke out
beyond minor raids.[65] Instead, popular discontent led to banditry and,
ultimately, full-scale rebellion. The civil war ended with the Liu clan on the
throne again, beginning the Eastern Han dynasty (25–220).[66]

The restorer [Emperor Guangwu](/wiki/Emperor_Guangwu_of_Han "Emperor Guangwu
of Han") (r. 25–57 AD) initiated several projects to consolidate his control
within the frontier regions. Defense works were established to the east of the
Yanmen Pass, with a line of fortifications and beacon fires stretching from
Pingcheng County (present-day [Datong](/wiki/Datong "Datong")) through the
valley of the [Sanggan River](/wiki/Sanggan_River "Sanggan River") to [Dai
County](/wiki/Dai_County "Dai County"), Shanxi.[67] By 38 AD, as a result of
raids by the Xiongnu further to the west against the Wei River valley, orders
were given for a series of walls to be constructed as defences for the [Fen
River](/wiki/Fen_River "Fen River"), the southward course of the Yellow River,
and the region of the former imperial capital, Chang'an.[68] These
constructions were defensive in nature, which marked a shift from the
offensive walls of the preceding Emperor Wu and the rulers of the Warring
States. By the early 40s AD the northern frontiers of China had undergone
drastic change: the line of the imperial frontier followed not the advanced
positions conquered by Emperor Wu but the rear defences indicated roughly by
the modern (Ming dynasty) Great Wall. The Ordos region, northern Shanxi, and
the upper [Luan River](/wiki/Luan_River "Luan River") basin around
[Chengde](/wiki/Chengde "Chengde")[69] were abandoned and left to the control
of the Xiongnu.[70] The rest of the frontier remained somewhat intact until
the [end of the Han dynasty](/wiki/End_of_the_Han_dynasty "End of the Han
dynasty"), with the [Dunhuang manuscripts](/wiki/Dunhuang_manuscripts
"Dunhuang manuscripts") (discovered in 1900) indicating that the military
establishment in the northwest was maintained for most of the Eastern Han
period.[71]

## Period of Disunity to the Sui dynasty
(220–618)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_Great_Wall_of_China&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Period of Disunity to the Sui dynasty \(220–618\)")]

Following the end of the Han dynasty in 220, China disintegrated into warlord
states, which in 280 were briefly reunited under the [Western
Jin](/wiki/Western_Jin "Western Jin") dynasty (265–316). There are ambiguous
accounts of the Jin rebuilding the Qin wall,[72] but these walls apparently
offered no resistance during the [Wu Hu uprising](/wiki/Wu_Hu_uprising "Wu Hu
uprising"), when the nomadic tribes of the steppe evicted the Chinese court
from northern China. What followed was a succession of short-lived states in
northern China known as the [Sixteen Kingdoms](/wiki/Sixteen_Kingdoms "Sixteen
Kingdoms"), until they were all consolidated by the [Xianbei](/wiki/Xianbei
"Xianbei")-led [Northern Wei](/wiki/Northern_Wei "Northern Wei") dynasty
(386–535).[73]

As Northern Wei became more economically dependent on agriculture, the Xianbei
emperors made a conscious decision to adopt Chinese customs, including passive
methods of frontier defence. In 423, a defence line over 2,000 _li_ (1,080
kilometres (670 mi)) long was built to resist the [Rouran](/wiki/Rouran
"Rouran"); its path roughly followed the old Zhao wall from
[Chicheng](/wiki/Chicheng "Chicheng") County in Hebei Province to [Wuyuan
County, Inner Mongolia](/wiki/Wuyuan_County,_Inner_Mongolia "Wuyuan County,
Inner Mongolia").[74] In 446, 100,000 men were put to work building an inner
wall from [Yanqing](/wiki/Yanqing_County "Yanqing County"), passing south of
the Wei capital [Pingcheng](/wiki/Pingcheng "Pingcheng"), and ending up near
Pingguan on the eastern bank of the Yellow River. The two walls formed the
basis of the double-layered [Xuanfu](/wiki/Xuanfu
"Xuanfu")–[Datong](/wiki/Datong "Datong") wall system that protected Beijing a
thousand years later during the Ming dynasty.[75]

The Northern Wei collapsed in 535 due to civil insurrection to be eventually
succeeded by the [Northern Qi](/wiki/Northern_Qi "Northern Qi") (550–575) and
[Northern Zhou](/wiki/Northern_Zhou "Northern Zhou") (557–580). Faced with the
threat of the [Göktürks](/wiki/G%C3%B6kt%C3%BCrks "Göktürks") from the north,
from 552 to 556 the Qi built up to 3,000 _li_ (about 1,600 kilometres (990
mi)) of wall from Shanxi to the sea at [Shanhai Pass](/wiki/Shanhai_Pass
"Shanhai Pass").[76] Over the course of the year 555 alone, 1.8 million men
were mobilized to build the [Juyong Pass](/wiki/Juyong_Pass "Juyong Pass") and
extend its wall by 450 kilometres (280 mi) through Datong to the eastern banks
of the Yellow River.[77] In 557 a secondary wall was built inside the main
one.[72] These walls were built quickly from local earth and stones or formed
by natural barriers. Two stretches of the stone-and-earth Qi wall still stand
in Shanxi today, measuring 3.3 metres (11 ft) wide at their bases and 3.5
metres (11 ft) high on average.[77] In 577 the Northern Zhou conquered the
Northern Qi and in 580 made repairs to the existing Qi walls. The route of the
Qi and Zhou walls would be mostly followed by the later Ming wall west of
[Gubeikou](/wiki/Gubeikou "Gubeikou"),[76] which includes reconstructed walls
from Qi and Zhou.[72] In more recent times, the reddish remnants of the Zhou
ramparts in Hebei gave rise to the nickname "Red Wall".[77]

The [Sui](/wiki/Sui_dynasty "Sui dynasty") took power from the Northern Zhou
in 581 before reuniting China in 589. Sui's founding emperor, [Emperor Wen of
Sui](/wiki/Emperor_Wen_of_Sui "Emperor Wen of Sui") (r. 581–604), carried out
considerable wall construction in 581 in Hebei and Shanxi to defend against
[Ishbara Qaghan](/wiki/Ishbara_Qaghan "Ishbara Qaghan") of the Göktürks. The
new walls proved insufficient in 582 when Ishbara Qaghan avoided them by
riding west to raid Gansu and Shaanxi with 400,000 archers.[78] Between 585
and 588 Emperor Wen sought to close this gap by putting walls up in the Ordos
Mountains (between [Suide](/wiki/Suide "Suide") and [Lingwu](/wiki/Lingwu
"Lingwu")) and Inner Mongolia. In 586 as many as 150,000 men are recorded as
involved in the construction.[79] Emperor Wen's son [Emperor
Yang](/wiki/Emperor_Yang_of_Sui "Emperor Yang of Sui") (r. 604–618) continued
to build walls. In 607–608 he sent over a million men to build a wall from
[Yulin](/wiki/Yulin,_Shaanxi "Yulin, Shaanxi") to near [Huhhot](/wiki/Huhhot
"Huhhot")[72] to protect the newly refurbished eastern capital
[Luoyang](/wiki/Luoyang "Luoyang").[80] Part of the Sui wall survives to this
day in Inner Mongolia as earthen ramparts some 2.5 metres (8 ft 2 in) high
with towers rising to double that.[80] The [dynastic history of
Sui](/wiki/Book_of_Sui "Book of Sui") estimates that 500,000 people died
building the wall,[81] adding to the number of casualties caused by Emperor
Yang's projects including the aforementioned redesign of Luoyang, the [Grand
Canal](/wiki/Grand_Canal_\(China\) "Grand Canal \(China\)"), and two ill-fated
[campaigns against Goguryeo](/wiki/Goguryeo%E2%80%93Sui_War "Goguryeo–Sui
War"). With the economy strained and the populace resentful, the Sui dynasty
erupted in rebellion and ended with the assassination of Emperor Yang in
618.[82]

## Tang dynasty
(618–907)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_Great_Wall_of_China&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Tang dynasty \(618–907\)")]

塞下曲 (望臨洮) **Under the Wall (Viewing Lintao)**

    飲馬渡秋水 _My horse crosses the river in autumn,_
    水寒風似刀 _The cold wind off the water cuts like a knife._
    平沙日未沒 _Across the desert flats, the day is not yet finished,_
    黯黯見臨洮 _I can dimly make out[Lintao](/wiki/Lintao "Lintao")._

    昔日長城戰 _In olden days, battles along the Long Wall_
    咸言意氣高 _Were described with praise and awe._
    黃塵足今古 _But today, the past is no more than yellow dust_
    白骨亂蓬蒿 _White bones jostled amongst the grass._

—[Wang Changling](/wiki/Wang_Changling "Wang Changling") (698–755)[83]

Frontier policy under the [Tang dynasty](/wiki/Tang_dynasty "Tang dynasty")
reversed the wall-building activities of most previous dynasties that had
occupied northern China since the third century BC, and no extensive wall
building took place for the next several hundred years.[84]

Soon after the establishment of the Tang dynasty, during the reign of [Emperor
Taizong](/wiki/Emperor_Taizong_of_Tang "Emperor Taizong of Tang") (r.
626–649), the threat of Göktürk tribesmen from the north prompted some court
officials to suggest drafting [corvée](/wiki/Corv%C3%A9e "Corvée") labourers
to repair the aging Great Wall. Taizong scoffed at the suggestion, alluding to
the Sui walls built in vain: "The Emperor Yang of Sui made the people labor to
construct the Great Wall in order to defend against the Turks, but in the end
this was of no use."[85] Instead of building walls, Taizong claimed he "need
merely to establish [Li Shiji](/wiki/Li_Shiji "Li Shiji") in
[Jinyang](/wiki/Taiyuan "Taiyuan") for the dust on the border to settle."[85]
Accordingly, Taizong sent talented generals like Li Shiji with mobile armies
to the frontier, while fortifications were mostly limited to a series of
walled garrisons, such as the euphemistically-named "cities for accepting
surrender" (受降城, _shòuxiáng chéng_) that were actually bases from which to
launch attacks.[84] As a result of this military strategy, the Tang grew to
become one of the largest of all the Chinese empires, destroying the Göktürks
of the [Eastern Turkic Khaganate](/wiki/Eastern_Turkic_Khaganate "Eastern
Turkic Khaganate") and acquiring territory stretching all the way to
[Kazakhstan](/wiki/Kazakhstan "Kazakhstan").[85]

Nevertheless, records show that in the Kaiyuan [era](/wiki/Chinese_era_name
"Chinese era name") (713–742) of [Emperor
Xuanzong](/wiki/Emperor_Xuanzong_of_Tang "Emperor Xuanzong of Tang")'s reign,
the general [Zhang Yue](/wiki/Zhang_Yue_\(Tang_dynasty\) "Zhang Yue \(Tang
dynasty\)") built a wall 90 _li_ (48 kilometres (30 mi)) to the north of
Huairong (懷戎; present-day [Huailai County](/wiki/Huailai_County "Huailai
County"), Hebei), although it remains unclear whether he erected new walls or
only reinforced the existing Northern Qi walls.[86]

The Great Wall, or the ruins of it, features prominently in the subset of
[Tang poetry](/wiki/Tang_poetry "Tang poetry") known as [_biansai
shi_](/wiki/Classical_Chinese_poetry_genres#Frontier_Fortress_\(邊塞,_出塞,_or_塞下曲\)
"Classical Chinese poetry genres") (邊塞詩, "frontier verse") written by scholar-
officials assigned along the frontier. Emphasizing the poets' loneliness and
longing for home while hinting at the pointlessness of their posts, these
frontier verses are characterized by imagery of desolate landscapes, including
the ruins of the now-neglected Great Wall—a direct product of Tang's frontier
policy.[87]

## Northern Song
(960-1127)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_Great_Wall_of_China&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Northern Song \(960-1127\)")]

See also: [History of the Song dynasty](/wiki/History_of_the_Song_dynasty
"History of the Song dynasty")

Han Chinese power during the tumultuous post-Tang era was represented by the
[Song dynasty](/wiki/Song_dynasty "Song dynasty") (960–1279), which completed
its unification of the Chinese states with the conquest of [Wuyue](/wiki/Wuyue
"Wuyue") in 971. Turning to the north after this victory, in 979 the Song
eliminated the [Northern Han](/wiki/Northern_Han "Northern Han"), ultimate
successors to the Later Jin, but were unable to take the Sixteen Prefectures
from the Liao dynasty.[88] As a result of Song's military aggression,
relations between the Song and Liao remained tense and hostile. One of the
battlegrounds in the [Song–Liao
War](/w/index.php?title=Song%E2%80%93Liao_War&action=edit&redlink=1 "Song–Liao
War \(page does not exist\)") was the Great Wall Gap (長城口), so named because
the southern Yan wall of the Warring States period crossed the Juma River here
into Liao territory.[28] The Great Wall Gap saw action in 979, 988–989, and
1004, and a Song fortress was built there in 980.[89] Intermittent wars
between the Song and the Liao lasted until January 1005, when a truce was
called and led to the [Treaty of Chanyuan](/wiki/Treaty_of_Chanyuan "Treaty of
Chanyuan"). This agreement, among other things, required the Song to pay
tribute to the Liao, recognized the Song and Liao as equals,[90] and
demarcated the Song–Liao border,[91] the course of which became more clearly
defined in a series of subsequent bilateral agreements. Several stretches of
the old Great Walls, including the Northern Qi Inner Wall near the [Hengshan
mountain range](/wiki/Mount_Heng_\(Shanxi\) "Mount Heng \(Shanxi\)"), became
the border between the Song and the Liao.[92]

In the northwest, the Song were in conflict with the Western Xia, since they
occupied what the Song considered as Chinese land lost during the Tang
dynasty. The Song utilized the walls built during the reign of Qin's King
Zhaoxiang of the Warring States period, making it the Song–Western Xia
border,[93] but the topography of the area was not as sharp and distinct as
the Song–Liao defences to the east. The border general [Cao
Wei](/w/index.php?title=Cao_Wei_\(Song_dynasty\)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Cao
Wei \(Song dynasty\) \(page does not exist\)") (曹瑋; 973–1030) deemed the Old
Wall itself insufficient to slow a Tangut cavalry attack, and had a deep
trench dug alongside. This trench, between 15 and 20 metres (49 and 66 feet)
in width and depth, proved an effective defence, but in 1002 the Tanguts
caught the Song patrollers off guard and filled the trench to cross the Old
Wall.[94] Later, in 1042, the Tanguts turned the trench against the Song by
removing the bridges over it, thereby trapping the retreating army of [Ge
Huaimin](/w/index.php?title=Ge_Huaimin&action=edit&redlink=1 "Ge Huaimin
\(page does not exist\)") (葛懷敏) before annihilating it at the [Battle of
Dingchuan
Fortress](/w/index.php?title=Battle_of_Dingchuan_Fortress&action=edit&redlink=1
"Battle of Dingchuan Fortress \(page does not exist\)") (定川寨).[95]

Despite the war with the Western Xia, the Song also settled land disputes with
them by referring to prior agreements, as with the Liao.[96] However, soon
after the Jin dynasty overthrew the Liao dynasty, the Jurchens [sacked the
Song capital in 1127](/wiki/Jingkang_Incident "Jingkang Incident") during the
[Jin–Song wars](/wiki/Jin%E2%80%93Song_wars "Jin–Song wars"), causing the Song
court to flee south of the [Yangtze River](/wiki/Yangtze_River "Yangtze
River"). For the next two and a half centuries, the Great Wall played no role
in Han Chinese geopolitics.[97]

## Conquest dynasties
(907-1368)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_Great_Wall_of_China&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Conquest dynasties \(907-1368\)")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/GreatWallChina3.png/220px-
GreatWallChina3.png)](/wiki/File:GreatWallChina3.png)

[](/wiki/File:GreatWallChina3.png "Enlarge")

The Jurchen Jin dynasty (orange) shown with the walls of Liao, Xia, and Jin.

After the Tang dynasty ended in 907, the northern frontier area remained out
of Han Chinese hands until the establishment of the [Ming
dynasty](/wiki/Ming_dynasty "Ming dynasty") in 1368. During this period, non-
Han "[conquest dynasties](/wiki/Conquest_Dynasties "Conquest Dynasties")"
ruled the north: the [Khitan](/wiki/Khitan_people "Khitan people") [Liao
dynasty](/wiki/Liao_dynasty "Liao dynasty") (907–1125) and the succeeding
[Jurchen](/wiki/Jurchen_people "Jurchen people") [Jin
dynasty](/wiki/Jin_dynasty_\(1115%E2%80%931234\) "Jin dynasty \(1115–1234\)")
(1115–1234) in the east and the [Tangut](/wiki/Tangut_people "Tangut people")
[Western Xia](/wiki/Western_Xia "Western Xia") (1038–1227) in the west, all of
which had built walls against the north.

### Liao dynasty
frontier[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_Great_Wall_of_China&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Liao dynasty frontier")]

In 907, the Khitan chieftain [Abaoji](/wiki/Abaoji "Abaoji") succeeded in
getting himself appointed [khaghan](/wiki/Khaghan "Khaghan") of all Khitan
tribes in the north, laying the foundations to what would officially become
the Liao dynasty. In 936, the Khitan supported the Shanxi rebel [Shi
Jingtang](/wiki/Shi_Jingtang "Shi Jingtang") in his revolt against the [Shatuo
Turkic](/wiki/Shatuo "Shatuo") [Later Tang](/wiki/Later_Tang "Later Tang"),
which had destroyed the usurpers of the Tang in 923.[98] The Khitan leader,
Abaoji's second son [Yelü Deguang](/wiki/Yel%C3%BC_Deguang "Yelü Deguang"),
convinced Shi to found a new dynasty (the [Later
Jin](/wiki/Later_Jin_\(Five_Dynasties\) "Later Jin \(Five Dynasties\)"),
936–946), and received the crucial border region known as the [Sixteen
Prefectures](/wiki/Sixteen_Prefectures "Sixteen Prefectures") in
return.[99][100] With the Sixteen Prefectures, the Khitan now possessed all
the passes and fortifications that controlled access to the plains of northern
China, including the main Great Wall line.[99]

Settling in the transitional area between agricultural lands and the steppe,
the Khitans became semi-sedentary like their Xianbei predecessors of the
Northern Wei, and started to use Chinese methods of defence. In 1026 walls
were built through central Manchuria north of [Nong'an
County](/wiki/Nong%27an_County "Nong'an County") to the banks of the [Songhua
River](/wiki/Songhua_River "Songhua River").[101]

### The two walls of Jin
dynasty[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_Great_Wall_of_China&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: The two walls of Jin dynasty")]

When the [Jurchens](/wiki/Jurchens "Jurchens"), once Liao vassals, rose up to
overthrow their masters and established the [Jin
dynasty](/wiki/Jin_dynasty_\(1115%E2%80%931234\) "Jin dynasty \(1115–1234\)"),
they continued Liao's wall-building activities with extensive work begun
before 1138.[102] Further wall construction took place in 1165 and 1181 under
the Jin [Emperor Shizhong](/wiki/Emperor_Shizong_of_Jin "Emperor Shizong of
Jin"), and later from 1192 to 1203 during the reign of his successor [Emperor
Zhangzong](/wiki/Emperor_Zhangzong_of_Jin "Emperor Zhangzong of Jin").[101]

This long period of wall-building burdened the populace and provoked
controversy. Sometime between 1190 and 1196, during Zhangzong's reign, the
high official [Zhang
Wangong](/w/index.php?title=Zhang_Wangong&action=edit&redlink=1 "Zhang Wangong
\(page does not exist\)") (張萬公) and the [Censorate](/wiki/Censorate
"Censorate") recommended that work on the wall be indefinitely suspended due
to a recent drought, noting: "What has been begun is already being flattened
by sandstorms, and bullying the people into defence works will simply exhaust
them."[103][104] However, [Chancellor](/wiki/Chancellor_\(China\) "Chancellor
\(China\)") [Wanyan
Xiang](/w/index.php?title=Wanyan_Xiang&action=edit&redlink=1 "Wanyan Xiang
\(page does not exist\)") (完顏襄) convinced the emperor of the walls' merits
based on an optimistic cost estimate – "Although the initial outlay for the
walls will be one million strings of cash, when the work is done the frontier
will be secure with only half the present number of soldiers needed to defend
it, which means that every year you will save three million strings of cash
... The benefits will be everlasting" – and so construction continued
unabated.[105][106] All this work created an extensive systems of walls, which
consisted of a 700 kilometres (430 mi) "outer wall" from
[Heilongjiang](/wiki/Heilongjiang "Heilongjiang") to Mongolia and a 1,000
kilometres (620 mi) network of "inner walls" north and northeast of Beijing.
Together, they formed a roughly elliptical web of fortifications 1,400
kilometres (870 mi) in length and 440 kilometres (270 mi) in diameter.[107]
Some of these walls had inner moats (from 10 to 60 metres (33 to 197 feet) in
width), beacon towers, [battlements](/wiki/Battlement "Battlement"),
[parapets](/wiki/Parapet "Parapet"), and outward-facing semicircular platforms
protruding from the wall—features that set the Jin walls apart from their
predecessors.[102]

### The Tangut Great
Wall[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_Great_Wall_of_China&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: The Tangut Great Wall")]

In the west, the [Tanguts](/wiki/Tangut_people "Tangut people") took control
of the Ordos region, where they established the [Western
Xia](/wiki/Western_Xia "Western Xia") dynasty.[108] Although the Tanguts were
not traditionally known for building walls, in 2011 archeologists uncovered
100 kilometres (62 mi) of walls at [Ömnögovi
Province](/wiki/%C3%96mn%C3%B6govi_Province "Ömnögovi Province") in Mongolia
in what had been Western Xia territory. Radiocarbon analysis showed that they
were constructed from 1040 to 1160. The walls were as tall as 2.75 metres (9
ft 0 in) at places when they were discovered, and may have been around 2
metres (6 ft 7 in) taller originally. They were built with mud and
[saxaul](/wiki/Saxaul "Saxaul") (a desert [shrub](/wiki/Shrub "Shrub")) in one
section, and dark [basalt](/wiki/Basalt "Basalt") blocks in another,
suggesting that the rocks may have been quarried from nearby extinct volcanoes
and transported to the construction site. Archaeologists have not yet found
traces of human activity around this stretch of wall, which suggests that the
Western Xia wall in this location may have been incomplete and not ready for
use.[4]

### The onset of the
Mongols[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_Great_Wall_of_China&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: The onset of the Mongols")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Yuntai_south_side.jpg/220px-
Yuntai_south_side.jpg)](/wiki/File:Yuntai_south_side.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Yuntai_south_side.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Cloud Platform at Juyong Pass](/wiki/Cloud_Platform_at_Juyong_Pass "Cloud
Platform at Juyong Pass")

See also: [Mongol invasion of China](/wiki/Mongol_invasion_of_China "Mongol
invasion of China")

In the 13th century, the Mongol leader [Genghis Khan](/wiki/Genghis_Khan
"Genghis Khan"), once a vassal of the Jurchens, rose up against the Jin
dynasty.[109] In the ensuing [Mongol conquest of the Jin
dynasty](/wiki/Mongol_conquest_of_the_Jin_dynasty "Mongol conquest of the Jin
dynasty"), the nomadic invaders avoided direct attacks on the Jin
fortifications. Instead, when they could, the Mongols simply rode around the
walls; an effective example of this tactic is in 1211, when they circumvented
the substantial fortress in Zhangjiakou and inflicted a terrible defeat upon
the Jin armies at the [Battle of Yehuling](/wiki/Battle_of_Yehuling "Battle of
Yehuling").[110] The Mongols also took advantage of lingering Liao resentment
against the Jin; the Khitan defenders of the garrisons along the Jin walls,
such as those in [Gubeikou](/wiki/Gubeikou "Gubeikou"), often preferred to
surrender to the Mongols rather than fight them.[111] The only major
engagement of note along the main Great Wall line was at the heavily defended
Juyong Pass: instead of laying siege, the Mongol general [Jebe](/wiki/Jebe
"Jebe") lured the defenders out into an ambush and charged in through the
opened gates.[111] In 1215, Genghis Khan besieged, captured, and sacked the
Jin capital of [Yanjing](/wiki/Yanjing "Yanjing") (modern-day Beijing). The
Jin dynasty eventually collapsed following the [siege of
Caizhou](/wiki/Siege_of_Caizhou "Siege of Caizhou") in 1234. Western Xia had
already [fallen in 1227](/wiki/Mongol_conquest_of_Western_Xia "Mongol conquest
of Western Xia"), and the Southern Song [resisted the Mongols until
1279](/wiki/Mongol_conquest_of_the_Song_dynasty "Mongol conquest of the Song
dynasty").

With that, the [Yuan dynasty](/wiki/Yuan_dynasty "Yuan dynasty"), established
by Genghis Khan's grandson [Khublai Khan](/wiki/Khublai_Khan "Khublai Khan"),
became the first foreign dynasty to rule all of China.[112] Despite being the
head of the [Mongol Empire](/wiki/Mongol_Empire "Mongol Empire"), Khublai
Khan's rule over China was not free from the threat of the steppe nomads.[113]
The Yuan dynasty faced challenges from rival claimants to the title of [Great
Khan](/wiki/Great_Khan "Great Khan") and from rebellious Mongols in the north.
Khublai Khan dealt with such threats by using both military blockades and
economic sanctions. Although he established garrisons along the steppe
frontier from the Juyan Lake Basin in the far west to
[Yingchang](/wiki/Yingchang "Yingchang") in the east,[114] Khublai Khan and
the Yuan emperors after him did not add to the Great Wall (except for the
ornate [Cloud Platform](/wiki/Cloud_Platform_at_Juyongguan "Cloud Platform at
Juyongguan") at Juyong Pass). When the Venetian traveller [Marco
Polo](/wiki/Marco_Polo "Marco Polo") wrote of his experiences in China during
the reign of Khublai Khan, he did not mention a Great Wall.[115]

## Ming dynasty
(1368–1644)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_Great_Wall_of_China&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Ming dynasty \(1368–1644\)")]

Main article: [Ming Great Wall](/wiki/Ming_Great_Wall "Ming Great Wall")

### The early
walls[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_Great_Wall_of_China&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: The early walls")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/GreatWallChina4.png/220px-
GreatWallChina4.png)](/wiki/File:GreatWallChina4.png)

[](/wiki/File:GreatWallChina4.png "Enlarge")

The extent of the Ming dynasty and its walls, which formed most of what is
called the Great Wall of China today

In 1368, the [Hongwu Emperor](/wiki/Hongwu_Emperor "Hongwu Emperor") ([Zhu
Yuanzhang](/wiki/Zhu_Yuanzhang "Zhu Yuanzhang"), r. 1368–98) ousted the
Mongol-led Yuan dynasty from China to inaugurate the [Ming
dynasty](/wiki/Ming_dynasty "Ming dynasty"). The Mongols fled back to
Mongolia, but even after numerous campaigns, the Mongol problem remained.[116]

During his early reign, Hongwu set up the "eight outer garrisons" close to the
steppe and an inner line of forts more suitable for defence. The inner line
was the forerunner to the Ming Great Wall.[117] In 1373, as Ming forces
encountered setbacks, Hongwu put more emphasis on defence and adopted [Hua
Yunlong](/w/index.php?title=Hua_Yunlong&action=edit&redlink=1 "Hua Yunlong
\(page does not exist\)")'s (華雲龍) suggestion to establish garrisons at 130
passes and other strategic points in the Beijing area.[118] More positions
were set up in the years up Hongwu's death in 1398, and watchtowers were
manned from the [Bohai Sea](/wiki/Bohai_Sea "Bohai Sea") to Beijing and
further onto the Mongolian steppes.[118][119] These positions, however, were
not for a linear defence but rather a regional one in which walls did not
feature heavily, and offensive tactics remained the overarching policy at the
time.[118] In 1421, the Ming capital was relocated from
[Nanjing](/wiki/Nanjing "Nanjing") in the south to Beijing in the north,
partly to better manage the Mongol situation. Thus defenses were concentrated
around Beijing, where stone and earth began to replace rammed earth in
strategic passes.[120] A wall was erected by the Ming in Liaodong to protect
Han settlers from a possible threat from the Jurched-Mongol Oriyanghan around
1442.[121] In 1467–68, expansion of the wall provided further protection for
the region from against attacks by the [Jianzhou
Jurchens](/wiki/Jianzhou_Jurchens "Jianzhou Jurchens") in the northeast.[122]

Meanwhile, the outer defenses were gradually moved inward, thereby sacrificing
a vital foothold in the steppe transitional zone.[123] Despite the withdrawal
from the steppe, the Ming military remained in a strong position against the
nomads until the [Tumu Crisis](/wiki/Tumu_Crisis "Tumu Crisis") in 1449, which
caused the collapse of the early Ming security system. Over half of the
campaigning Chinese army perished in the conflict, while the Mongols captured
the [Zhengtong Emperor](/wiki/Zhengtong_Emperor "Zhengtong Emperor"). This
military debacle shattered the Chinese military might that had so impressed
and given pause to the Mongols since the beginning of the dynasty, and caused
the Ming to be on the defensive ever after.[124]

The deterioration of the Ming military position in the steppe transitional
zone gave rise to nomadic raids into Ming territory, including the crucial
Ordos region, on a level unprecedented since the dynasty's founding. After
decades of deliberation between an offensive strategy and an accommodative
policy, the decision to build the first major Ming walls in the Ordos was
agreed upon as an acceptable compromise the 1470s.[125]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Jinshangling2.jpg/220px-
Jinshangling2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jinshangling2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Jinshangling2.jpg "Enlarge")

A section of the Great Wall at [Jinshanling](/wiki/Jinshanling "Jinshanling")
in [Luanping County](/wiki/Luanping_County "Luanping County"),
[Hebei](/wiki/Hebei "Hebei") province, China

[Yu Zijun](/w/index.php?title=Yu_Zijun&action=edit&redlink=1 "Yu Zijun \(page
does not exist\)") (余子俊; 1429–1489) first proposed constructing a wall in the
Ordos region in August 1471,[126] but not until 20 December 1472 did the court
and emperor approve the plan. The 1473 victory in the [Battle of Red Salt
Lake](/w/index.php?title=Battle_of_Red_Salt_Lake&action=edit&redlink=1 "Battle
of Red Salt Lake \(page does not exist\)") (紅鹽池) by [Wang
Yue](/w/index.php?title=Wang_Yue_\(Ming_dynasty\)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Wang
Yue \(Ming dynasty\) \(page does not exist\)") (王越) deterred Mongol invasions
long enough for Yu Zijun to complete his wall project in 1474. This wall, a
combined effort between Yu Zijun and Wang Yue, stretched from present day
Hengcheng (橫城) in [Lingwu](/wiki/Lingwu "Lingwu") (northwestern
[Ningxia](/wiki/Ningxia "Ningxia") province) to Huamachi town (花馬池鎮) in
[Yanchi County](/wiki/Yanchi_County "Yanchi County"), and from there to
Qingshuiying (清水營) in northeastern Shaanxi, a total of more than 2000 _li_
(about 1,100 kilometres (680 mi)) long. Along its length were 800 strong
points, sentry posts, beacon-fire towers, and assorted defences. 40,000 men
were enlisted for this effort, which was completed in several months at a cost
of over one million silver [taels](/wiki/Tael "Tael"). This defence system
proved its initial worth in 1482, when a large group of Mongol raiders were
trapped within the double lines of fortifications and suffered a defeat by the
Ming generals. This was seen as a vindication of Yu Zijun's strategy of wall-
building by the people of the border areas.[127] By the mid-16th century, Yu's
wall in the Ordos had seen expansion into an extensive defence system. It
contained two defence lines: Yu's wall, called the "great border" (大邊,
_dàbiān_), and a "secondary border" (二邊, _èrbiān_) built by [Yang
Yiqing](/w/index.php?title=Yang_Yiqing&action=edit&redlink=1 "Yang Yiqing
\(page does not exist\)") (楊一清; 1454–1530) behind it.[128]

Following the success of the Ordos walls, Yu Zijun proposed construction of a
further wall that would extend from the Yellow River bend in the Ordos to the
Sihaiye Pass (四海冶口; in present-day [Yanqing County](/wiki/Yanqing_County
"Yanqing County")) near the capital Beijing, running a distance of more than
1300 _li_ (about 700 kilometres (430 mi)).[129] The project received approval
in 1485, but Yu's political enemies harped on the cost overruns and forced Yu
to scrap the project and retire the same year. For more than 50 years after
Yu's resignation, political struggle prevented major wall constructions on a
scale comparable to Yu's Ordos project.[130]

However, wall construction continued regardless of court politics during this
time. The Ordos walls underwent extension, elaboration, and repair well into
the 16th century.[128] Brick and stone started to replace tamped earth as the
wall building material, because they offered better protection and durability.
This change in material gave rise to a number of necessary accommodations with
regard to logistics, and inevitably a drastic increase in costs. Instead of
being able to draw on local resources, building projects now required brick-
kilns, quarries, and transportation routes to deliver bricks to the work site.
Also, masons had to be hired since the local peasantry proved inadequate for
the level of sophistication that brick constructions required. Work that
originally could be done by one man in a month with earth now required 100 men
to do in stone.[131]

### The Walls of Xuanfu–Datong and the western
reaches[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_Great_Wall_of_China&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: The Walls of Xuanfu–Datong and the western reaches")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Dajingmen_03_July_2%2C2010.jpg/220px-
Dajingmen_03_July_2%2C2010.jpg)](/wiki/File:Dajingmen_03_July_2,2010.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Dajingmen_03_July_2,2010.jpg "Enlarge")

The Great Wall at [Dajingmen](/wiki/Dajingmen "Dajingmen"), part of the Xuanfu
stretch of the Great Wall. The gate structure is a Qing dynasty construction.

With the Ordos now adequately fortified, the Mongols avoided its walls by
riding east to invade [Datong](/wiki/Datong "Datong") and Xuanfu (宣府; present-
day [Xuanhua](/wiki/Xuanhua_District "Xuanhua District"), Hebei Province),
which were two major garrisons guarding the corridor to Beijing where no walls
had been built.[131] The two defence lines of Xuanfu and Datong (abbreviated
as "Xuan–Da") left by the Northern Qi and the early Ming had deteriorated by
this point, and for all intents and purposes the inner line was the capital's
main line of defence.[132]

From 1544 to 1549, [Weng
Wanda](/w/index.php?title=Weng_Wanda&action=edit&redlink=1 "Weng Wanda \(page
does not exist\)") (翁萬達; 1498–1552) embarked on a defensive building program
on a scale unprecedented in Chinese history.[133] Troops were re-deployed
along the outer line, new walls and beacon towers were constructed, and
fortifications were restored and extended along both lines.
[Firearms](/wiki/Firearms "Firearms") and [artillery](/wiki/Artillery
"Artillery") were mounted on the walls and towers during this time, for both
defence and signalling purposes.[134] The project's completion was announced
in the sixth month of 1548. At its height, the Xuan–Da portion of the Great
Wall totalled about 850 kilometres (530 miles) of wall, with some sections
being doubled-up with two lines of wall, some tripled or even quadrupled. The
outer frontier was now protected by a wall called the "outer border" (外邊,
_wàibiān_) that extended 380 kilometres (240 mi) from the Yellow River's edge
at the Piantou Pass (偏頭關) along the Inner Mongolia border with Shanxi into
Hebei province; the "inner border" wall (內邊, _nèibiān_) ran southeast from
Piantou Pass for some 400 kilometres (250 mi), ending at the [Pingxing
Pass](/wiki/Pingxing_Pass "Pingxing Pass"); a "river wall" (河邊, _hébiān_) also
ran from the Piantou Pass and followed the Yellow River southwards for about
70 kilometres (43 mi).[135]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Overhanging_Wall.JPG/220px-
Overhanging_Wall.JPG)](/wiki/File:Overhanging_Wall.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Overhanging_Wall.JPG "Enlarge")

A section of the Great Wall on the Hanging Cliffs (懸壁長城) leading up to [Jiayu
Pass](/wiki/Jiayu_Pass "Jiayu Pass")

As with Yu Zijun's wall in the Ordos, the Mongols shifted their attacks away
from the newly strengthened Xuan–Da sector to less well-protected areas. In
the west, [Shaanxi province](/wiki/Shaanxi "Shaanxi") became the target of
nomads riding west from the Yellow River loop.[135] The westernmost fortress
of Ming China, the [Jiayu Pass](/wiki/Jiayu_Pass "Jiayu Pass"), saw
substantial enhancement with walls starting in 1539, and from there border
walls were built discontinuously down the Hexi Corridor to
[Wuwei](/wiki/Wuwei,_Gansu "Wuwei, Gansu"), where the low earthen wall split
into two. The northern section passed through [Zhongwei](/wiki/Zhongwei
"Zhongwei") and [Yinchuan](/wiki/Yinchuan "Yinchuan"), where it met the
western edge of the Yellow River loop before connecting with the Ordos walls,
while the southern section passed through [Lanzhou](/wiki/Lanzhou "Lanzhou")
and continued northeast to [Dingbian](/wiki/Dingbian "Dingbian"). The origins
and the exact route of this so-called "Tibetan loop" are still not clear.[136]

### From Beijing to Shanhai
Pass[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_Great_Wall_of_China&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: From Beijing to Shanhai Pass")]

In 1550, having once more been refused a request for trade, the
[Tümed](/wiki/T%C3%BCmed "Tümed") Mongols under [Altan Khan](/wiki/Altan_Khan
"Altan Khan") invaded the Xuan–Da region. However, despite several attempts,
he could not take Xuanfu due to Weng Wanda's double fortified line while the
garrison at Datong bribed him to not attack there.[133] Instead of continuing
to operate in the area, he circled around Weng Wanda's wall to the relatively
lightly defended [Gubeikou](/wiki/Gubeikou "Gubeikou"), northeast of Beijing.
From there Altan Khan passed through the defences and raided the suburbs of
Beijing. According to one contemporary source, the raid took more than 60,000
lives and an additional 40,000 people became prisoners. As a response to this
raid, the focus of the Ming's northern defences shifted from the Xuan–Da
region to the Jizhou (薊州鎮) and Changping Defence Commands (昌平鎮) where the
breach took place.[137] Later in the same year, the dry-stone walls of the
Jizhou–Changping area (abbreviated as "Ji–Chang") were replaced by stone and
mortar. These allowed the Chinese to build on steeper, more easily defended
slopes and facilitated construction of features such as
[ramparts](/wiki/Defensive_wall "Defensive wall"),
[crenelations](/wiki/Battlement "Battlement"), and [peepholes](/wiki/Peephole
"Peephole").[138] The effectiveness of the new walls was demonstrated in the
failed Mongol raid of 1554, where raiders expecting a repeat of the events of
1550 were surprised by the higher wall and stiff Chinese resistance.[139]

In 1567 [Qi Jiguang](/wiki/Qi_Jiguang "Qi Jiguang") and [Tan
Lun](/wiki/Tan_Lun "Tan Lun"), successful generals who fended off the [coastal
pirates](/wiki/Jiajing_wokou_raids "Jiajing wokou raids"), were reassigned to
manage the Ji–Chang Defense Commands and step up the defences of the capital
region. Under their ambitious and energetic management, 1200 brick watchtowers
were built along the Great Wall from 1569 to 1571.[140] These included the
first large-scale use of hollow watchtowers on the Wall: up until this point,
most previous towers along the Great Wall had been solid, with a small hut on
top for a sentry to take shelter from the elements and Mongol arrows; the
Ji–Chang towers built from 1569 onwards were hollow brick structures, allowing
soldiers interior space to live, store food and water, stockpile weapons, and
take shelter from Mongol arrows.[141]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Shanhaiguan.gif/220px-
Shanhaiguan.gif)](/wiki/File:Shanhaiguan.gif)

[](/wiki/File:Shanhaiguan.gif "Enlarge")

Illustration of the Shanhai Pass garrison at the time of the Manchu conquests

Altan Khan eventually made peace with China when it opened border cities for
trade in 1571, alleviating the Mongol need to raid. This, coupled with Qi and
Tan's efforts to secure the frontier, brought a period of relative peace along
the border. However, minor raids still happened from time to time when the
profits of plunder outweighed those of trade,[137] prompting the Ming to close
all gaps along the frontier around Beijing. Areas of difficult terrain once
considered impassable were also walled off, leading to the well-known vistas
of a stone-faced Great Wall snaking over dramatic landscapes that tourists
still see today.[142]

Wall construction continued until the demise of the Ming dynasty in 1644.[143]
In the decades that led to the [fall of the Ming
dynasty](/wiki/Fall_of_the_Ming_dynasty "Fall of the Ming dynasty"), the Ming
court and the Great Wall itself had to deal with simultaneous internal
rebellions and the [Manchu invasions](/wiki/Manchu_conquest_of_China "Manchu
conquest of China"). In addition to their conquest of Liaodong, the Manchus
had raided across the Great Wall for the first time [in
1629](/wiki/Jisi_Incident "Jisi Incident"),[144] and again in 1634,[145]
1638,[146] and 1642.[147] Meanwhile, the rebels led by warlord [Li
Zicheng](/wiki/Li_Zicheng "Li Zicheng") had been gathering strength. In the
early months of 1644, Li Zicheng declared himself the founder of the
[Shun](/wiki/Shun_dynasty "Shun dynasty") and marched towards the Ming capital
from Shaanxi. His route roughly followed the line of the Great Wall, in order
to neutralize its heavily fortified garrisons.[148] The crucial defences of
Datong, Xuanfu, and Juyong Pass all surrendered without a fight, and the
[Chongzhen Emperor](/wiki/Chongzhen_Emperor "Chongzhen Emperor") hanged
himself on 25 April as the Shun army entered Beijing.[149] At this point, the
largest remaining Ming fighting force in North China was in Shanhai Pass,
where the Great Wall meets the Bohai Sea. Its defender [Wu
Sangui](/wiki/Wu_Sangui "Wu Sangui"), wedged between the Shun army within and
the Manchus without, decided to surrender to the Manchus and opened the gates
for them.[150] The Manchus, having thus entered through the Great Wall,
defeated Li Zicheng at the [Battle of Shanhai
Pass](/wiki/Battle_of_Shanhai_Pass "Battle of Shanhai Pass") and seized
Beijing on June 5\. They eventually defeated both the rebel-founded Shun
dynasty and the [remaining Ming resistance](/wiki/Southern_Ming "Southern
Ming"), establishing their rule over all of China as the Qing dynasty.[151]

Opinions about the Wall's role in the Ming dynasty's downfall are mixed.
Historians such as [Arthur Waldron](/wiki/Arthur_Waldron "Arthur Waldron") and
[Julia Lovell](/wiki/Julia_Lovell "Julia Lovell") are critical of the whole
wall-building exercise in light of its ultimate failure in protecting China;
the former compared the Great Wall with the failed [Maginot
Line](/wiki/Maginot_Line "Maginot Line") of the French in [World War
II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II").[152] However, independent scholar
[David Spindler](/wiki/David_Spindler "David Spindler") notes that the Wall,
being only part of a complex foreign policy, received "disproportionate blame"
because it was the most obvious relic of that policy.[153]

## Qing dynasty
(1644–1911)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_Great_Wall_of_China&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Qing dynasty \(1644–1911\)")]

The usefulness of the Great Wall as a defence line against northern nomads
became questionable under the Qing dynasty, since their territory encompassed
vast areas inside and outside the wall: China proper, Manchuria, and Mongolia
were all under Qing control. So instead, the Great Wall became the means to
limit Han Chinese movement into the steppes. In the case of Manchuria,
considered to be the sacred homeland by the ruling Manchu elites, some parts
of the Ming Liaodong Wall were repaired so it could serve to control Han
Chinese movement into Manchuria alongside the newly erected [Willow
Palisade](/wiki/Willow_Palisade "Willow Palisade").[154]

Culturally, the wall's symbolic role as a line between civilized society and
barbarism was suppressed by the Qing, who were keen to weaken the Han
culturalism that had been propagated by the Ming. As a result, no special
attention was paid to the Great Wall until the mid-Qing dynasty, when
Westerners started to show interest in the structure.[155]

### Western appreciation of the
Wall[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_Great_Wall_of_China&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Western appreciation of the Wall")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Kircher_-
_China_Illustrata_-_217_-_Great_Wall.jpg/220px-Kircher_-
_China_Illustrata_-_217_-_Great_Wall.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kircher_-
_China_Illustrata_-_217_-_Great_Wall.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Kircher_-_China_Illustrata_-_217_-_Great_Wall.jpg "Enlarge")

"A gate of the Wall of China, explaining its structure". An illustration from
[Athanasius Kircher](/wiki/Athanasius_Kircher "Athanasius Kircher")'s _[China
Illustrata](/wiki/China_Illustrata "China Illustrata")_ , 1667.

The existence of a colossal wall in Asia had circulated in the Middle East and
the West even before the first Europeans arrived in China by sea. The [late
antiquity](/wiki/Late_antiquity "Late antiquity") historian [Ammianus
Marcellinus](/wiki/Ammianus_Marcellinus "Ammianus Marcellinus") (330?–395?)
mentioned "summits of lofty walls" enclosing the land of [Seres](/wiki/Seres
"Seres"), the country that the Romans believed to be at the eastern end of the
[Silk Road](/wiki/Silk_Road "Silk Road").[156] In legend, the tribes of [Gog
and Magog](/wiki/Gog_and_Magog "Gog and Magog") were said to have been locked
out by [Alexander the Great](/wiki/Alexander_the_Great "Alexander the Great")
with [walls of steel](/wiki/Gates_of_Alexander "Gates of Alexander"). Later
Arab writers and travellers, such as [Rashid-al-Din Hamadani](/wiki/Rashid-al-
Din_Hamadani "Rashid-al-Din Hamadani") (1248–1318) and [Ibn
Battuta](/wiki/Ibn_Battuta "Ibn Battuta") (1304–1377), would erroneously
identify the Great Wall in China with the walls of the [Alexander
romances](/wiki/Alexander_romances "Alexander romances").[157] Soon after
Europeans reached Ming China in the early 16th century, accounts of the Great
Wall started to circulate in Europe, even though no European would see it with
their own eyes for another century. The work _A Treatise of China and the
Adjoyning Regions_ by [Gaspar da Cruz](/wiki/Gaspar_da_Cruz "Gaspar da Cruz")
(c. 1520–70) offered an early discussion of the Great Wall in which he noted,
"a Wall of an hundred [leagues](/wiki/League_\(unit\) "League \(unit\)") in
length. And some will affirme to bee more than a hundred leagues."[158]
Another early account written by Bishop [Juan González de
Mendoza](/wiki/Juan_Gonz%C3%A1lez_de_Mendoza "Juan González de Mendoza")
(1550–1620) reported a wall five hundred leagues long, but suggested that only
one hundred leagues were man-made, with the rest natural rock formations.[158]
The [Jesuit](/wiki/Jesuit "Jesuit") priest [Matteo Ricci](/wiki/Matteo_Ricci
"Matteo Ricci") (1552–1610) mentioned the Great Wall once in his diary, noting
the existence of "a tremendous wall four hundred and five miles long" that
formed part of the northern defences of the Ming Empire.[158]

Europeans first witnessed the Great Wall in the early 1600s. Perhaps the first
recorded instance of a European actually entering China via the Great Wall
came in 1605, when the Portuguese Jesuit brother [Bento de
Góis](/wiki/Bento_de_G%C3%B3is "Bento de Góis") reached the northwestern
[Jiayu Pass](/wiki/Jiayu_Pass "Jiayu Pass") from India.[159] [Ivan
Petlin](/wiki/Ivan_Petlin "Ivan Petlin")'s 1619 deposition for his Russian
embassy mission offers an early account based on a first-hand encounter with
the Great Wall, and mentions that in the course of the journey his embassy
travelled alongside the Great Wall for ten days.[160]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Allom_-
_The_Great_Wall_of_China.jpg/250px-Allom_-
_The_Great_Wall_of_China.jpg)](/wiki/File:Allom_-_The_Great_Wall_of_China.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Allom_-_The_Great_Wall_of_China.jpg "Enlarge")

The Great Wall as depicted in [Thomas Allom](/wiki/Thomas_Allom "Thomas
Allom")'s 1845 _China, in a series of views_

Early European accounts were mostly modest and empirical, closely mirroring
contemporary Chinese understanding of the Wall.[161] However, when the Ming
Great Wall began to take on a shape recognizable today, foreign accounts of
the Wall slid into hyperbole.[162] In the _[Atlas
Sinensis](/w/index.php?title=Atlas_Sinensis&action=edit&redlink=1 "Atlas
Sinensis \(page does not exist\)")_ published in 1665, the Jesuit [Martino
Martini](/wiki/Martino_Martini "Martino Martini") described elaborate but
atypical stretches of the Great Wall and generalized such fortifications
across the whole northern frontier. Furthermore, Martini erroneously
identified the Ming Wall as the same wall built by Qin Shi Huang in the 3rd
century BC, thereby exaggerating both the Wall's antiquity and its size. This
misconception was compounded by the _[China Illustrata](/wiki/China_Illustrata
"China Illustrata")_ of Father [Athanasius Kircher](/wiki/Athanasius_Kircher
"Athanasius Kircher") (1602–80), which provided pictures of the Great Wall as
imagined by a European illustrator.[162] All these and other accounts from
missionaries in China contributed to the [Orientalism](/wiki/Orientalism
"Orientalism") of the eighteenth century, in which a mythical China and its
exaggerated Great Wall feature prominently. The French philosopher
[Voltaire](/wiki/Voltaire "Voltaire") (1694–1774), for example, frequently
wrote about the Great Wall, although his feelings towards it oscillate between
unreserved admiration and condemnation of it as a "monument to fear".[163] The
[Macartney Embassy](/wiki/Macartney_Embassy "Macartney Embassy") of 1793
passed through the Great Wall at [Gubeikou](/wiki/Gubeikou "Gubeikou") on the
way to see the [Qianlong Emperor](/wiki/Qianlong_Emperor "Qianlong Emperor")
in [Chengde](/wiki/Chengde "Chengde"), who was there for the annual [imperial
hunt](/wiki/Imperial_hunt_of_the_Qing_dynasty "Imperial hunt of the Qing
dynasty"). One of the embassy's members, [John
Barrow](/wiki/Sir_John_Barrow,_1st_Baronet "Sir John Barrow, 1st Baronet"),
later founder of the [Royal Geographical
Society](/wiki/Royal_Geographical_Society "Royal Geographical Society"),
spuriously calculated that the amount of stone in the Wall was equivalent to
"all the dwelling houses of England and Scotland" and would suffice to
encircle the Earth at the equator twice.[164] The illustrations of the Great
Wall by Lieutenant Henry William Parish during this mission would be
reproduced in influential works such as [Thomas Allom](/wiki/Thomas_Allom
"Thomas Allom")'s 1845 _China, in a series of views_.[165]

Exposure to such works brought many foreign visitors to the Great Wall after
China opened its borders as a result of the nation's defeat in the [Opium
Wars](/wiki/Opium_Wars "Opium Wars") of the mid-19th century at the hands of
Britain and the other Western powers. The Juyong Pass near Beijing and the
"Old Dragon Head," where the Great Wall meets the sea at the [Shanhai
Pass](/wiki/Shanhai_Pass "Shanhai Pass"), proved popular destinations for
these wall watchers.[165]

The travelogues of the later 19th century in turn further contributed to the
elaboration and propagation of the Great Wall myth.[165] Examples of this
myth's growth are the false but widespread belief that the Great Wall of China
is visible from the Moon[166][167] or Mars.[168]

## Modern China
(1911–present)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_Great_Wall_of_China&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Modern China \(1911–present\)")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Greatwall_large.jpg/220px-
Greatwall_large.jpg)](/wiki/File:Greatwall_large.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Greatwall_large.jpg "Enlarge")

The Great Wall in 1907

The [Xinhai Revolution](/wiki/Xinhai_Revolution "Xinhai Revolution") in 1911
forced the abdication of the last Qing Emperor [Puyi](/wiki/Puyi "Puyi") and
ended China's last imperial dynasty. The revolutionaries, headed by [Sun Yat-
sen](/wiki/Sun_Yat-sen "Sun Yat-sen"), were concerned with creating a modern
sense of national identity in the chaotic post-imperial era. In contrast to
Chinese academics such as [Liang Qichao](/wiki/Liang_Qichao "Liang Qichao"),
who tried to counter the West's fantastic version of the Great Wall,[168] Sun
Yat-sen held the view that Qin Shi Huang's wall preserved the Chinese race,
and without it Chinese culture would not have developed enough to expand to
the south and assimilate foreign conquerors. Such an endorsement from the
"Father of Modern China" started to transform the Great Wall into a national
symbol in the Chinese consciousness, though this transformation was hampered
by conflicting views of nationalism with regard to the nascent "new
China."[169]

The failure of the new [Republic of
China](/wiki/Republic_of_China_\(1912%E2%80%9349\) "Republic of China
\(1912–49\)") fanned disillusionment with traditional Chinese culture and
ushered in the [New Culture Movement](/wiki/New_Culture_Movement "New Culture
Movement") and the [May Fourth Movement](/wiki/May_Fourth_Movement "May Fourth
Movement") of the mid-1910s and 1920s that aimed to dislodge China's future
trajectory from its past. Naturally, the Great Wall of China came under attack
as a symbol of the past. For example, an influential writer of this period,
[Lu Xun](/wiki/Lu_Xun "Lu Xun"), harshly criticized the "mighty and accursed
Great Wall"[169] in a short essay: "In reality, it has never served any
purpose than to make countless workers labour to death in vain ... [It]
surrounds everyone."[170]

Arise! All those who don't want to be slaves!  
Let our flesh and blood forge our new Great Wall!

"[The March of the Volunteers](/wiki/The_March_of_the_Volunteers "The March of
the Volunteers")"

The [Sino-Japanese conflict](/wiki/Second_Sino-Japanese_War "Second Sino-
Japanese War") (1931–45) gave the Great Wall a new lease of life in the eyes
of the Chinese. During the 1933 [defence of the Great
Wall](/wiki/Defence_of_the_Great_Wall "Defence of the Great Wall"),
inadequately-equipped Chinese soldiers held off double their number of
Japanese troops for several months. Using the cover of the Great Wall, the
Chinese – who were at times only armed with broadswords – were able to beat
off a Japanese advance that had the support of aerial bombardment.[171] With
the Chinese forces eventually overrun, the subsequent [Tanggu
Truce](/wiki/Tanggu_Truce "Tanggu Truce") stipulated that the Great Wall was
to become a demilitarized zone separating China and the newly created Japanese
[puppet state](/wiki/Puppet_state "Puppet state") of
[Manchukuo](/wiki/Manchukuo "Manchukuo"). Even so, the determined defence of
the Great Wall made it a symbol of Chinese patriotism and the resoluteness of
the Chinese people.[172] The [Chinese Communist](/wiki/Chinese_Communist
"Chinese Communist") leader [Mao Zedong](/wiki/Mao_Zedong "Mao Zedong") picked
up this symbol in [his poetry](/wiki/Poetry_of_Mao_Zedong "Poetry of Mao
Zedong") during his "[Long March](/wiki/Long_March "Long March")" escaping
from [Kuomintang](/wiki/Kuomintang "Kuomintang") prosecution. Near the end of
the trek in 1935, Mao wrote the poem "Mount Liupan" that contains the well-
known line that would be carved in stone along the Great Wall in the present
day: "Those who fail to reach the Great Wall are not true men" (不到长城非好汉).[173]
Another noteworthy reference to the Great Wall is in the song "[The March of
the Volunteers](/wiki/The_March_of_the_Volunteers "The March of the
Volunteers")", whose words came from a stanza in [Tian Han](/wiki/Tian_Han
"Tian Han")'s 1934 poem entitled "The Great Wall".[174] The song, originally
from the anti-Japanese movie _[Children of Troubled
Times](/wiki/Children_of_Troubled_Times "Children of Troubled Times")_ ,
enjoyed continued popularity in China and was selected as the provisional
[national anthem](/wiki/National_anthem "National anthem") of the [People's
Republic of China](/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_China "People's Republic of
China") (PRC) at its establishment in 1949.[175][176]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/President_Richard_and_Pat_Nixon_on_Great_Wall.png/220px-
President_Richard_and_Pat_Nixon_on_Great_Wall.png)](/wiki/File:President_Richard_and_Pat_Nixon_on_Great_Wall.png)

[](/wiki/File:President_Richard_and_Pat_Nixon_on_Great_Wall.png "Enlarge")

[US President Nixon](/wiki/1972_Nixon_visit_to_China "1972 Nixon visit to
China") visits the Great Wall, 1972

In 1952, the scholar-turned-bureaucrat [Guo Moruo](/wiki/Guo_Moruo "Guo
Moruo") laid out the first modern proposal to repair the Great Wall. Five
years later, the renovated [Badaling](/wiki/Badaling "Badaling") became the
first section to be opened to the public since the establishment of the
PRC.[177] The Badaling Great Wall has since become a staple stop for foreign
dignitaries who come to China, beginning with Nepali prime minister
[Bishweshwar Prasad Koirala](/wiki/Bishweshwar_Prasad_Koirala "Bishweshwar
Prasad Koirala") in 1960,[178] and most notably the American president
[Richard Nixon](/wiki/Richard_Nixon "Richard Nixon") in his historic [1972
visit to China](/wiki/1972_Nixon_visit_to_China "1972 Nixon visit to
China").[179] To date, Badaling is still the most visited stretch of the Great
Wall.[180]

Other stretches did not fare so well. During the [Cultural
Revolution](/wiki/Cultural_Revolution "Cultural Revolution") (1966–76),
hundreds of kilometres of the Great Wall—already damaged in the wars of the
last century and eroded by wind and rain—were deliberately destroyed by
fervent [Red Guards](/wiki/Red_Guards_\(China\) "Red Guards \(China\)") who
regarded it as part of the "[Four Olds](/wiki/Four_Olds "Four Olds")" to be
eradicated in the new China. Quarrying machines and even dynamite were used to
dismantle the Wall, and the pilfered materials were used for construction.[3]

As China [opened up in the 1980s](/wiki/Chinese_economic_reform "Chinese
economic reform"), reformist leader [Deng Xiaoping](/wiki/Deng_Xiaoping "Deng
Xiaoping") initiated the "Love our China and restore our Great Wall" campaign
(爱我中华，修我长城) to repair and preserve the Great Wall.[181] The Great Wall was
designated as a [UNESCO World Heritage Site](/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site
"UNESCO World Heritage Site") in 1987.[5] However, while tourism boomed over
the years, slipshod restoration methods have left sections of the Great Wall
near Beijing "looking like a Hollywood set" in the words of the _[National
Geographic News](/wiki/National_Geographic_News "National Geographic
News")_.[182] The less prominent stretches of the Great Wall did not get as
much attention. In 2002 the New York-based [World Monuments
Fund](/wiki/World_Monuments_Fund "World Monuments Fund") put the Great Wall on
its list of the [World's 100 Most Endangered
Sites](/wiki/2002_World_Monuments_Watch "2002 World Monuments Watch"). In 2003
the Chinese government began to enact laws to protect the Great Wall.[182]

##
Historiography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_Great_Wall_of_China&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Historiography")]

See also: [Chinese historiography](/wiki/Chinese_historiography "Chinese
historiography") and [Sinology](/wiki/Sinology "Sinology")

In China, one of the first individuals to attempt a multi-dynastic history of
the Great Wall was the 17th-century scholar [Gu Yanwu](/wiki/Gu_Yanwu "Gu
Yanwu"). More recently, in the 1930s and 1940s, Wang Guoliang (王國良) and Shou
Pengfei (壽鵬飛) produced exhaustive studies that culled extant literary records
to date and mapped the courses of early border walls. However, these efforts
were based solely on written records that contain obscure place names and
elusive literary references.[183]

The rise of modern archeology has contributed much to the study of the Great
Wall, either in corroborating existing research or in refuting it. However
these efforts do not yet give a full picture of the Great Wall's history, as
many wall sites dating to the [Period of Disunity](/wiki/Period_of_Disunity
"Period of Disunity") (220–589) had been overlaid by the extant Ming Great
Wall.[183]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Chinesische_Mauer_%28Ortelius_1584%29.jpg/220px-
Chinesische_Mauer_%28Ortelius_1584%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Chinesische_Mauer_\(Ortelius_1584\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Chinesische_Mauer_\(Ortelius_1584\).jpg "Enlarge")

The first map of China printed in a European atlas, engraved by [Abraham
Ortelius](/wiki/Abraham_Ortelius "Abraham Ortelius") (1584), shows a series of
walls wedged between mountains against the Tartars, represented by
[yurts](/wiki/Yurt "Yurt").

Western scholarship of the Great Wall was, until recently, affected by
misconceptions derived from traditional accounts of the Wall. When the Jesuits
brought back the first reports of the Wall to the West, European scholars were
puzzled that Marco Polo had not mentioned the presumably perennial "Great
Wall" in his _[Travels](/wiki/Travels_of_Marco_Polo "Travels of Marco Polo")_.
Some 17th-century scholars reasoned that the Wall must have been built in the
Ming dynasty, after Marco Polo's departure. This view was soon replaced by
another that argued, against Polo's own account, that the Venetian merchant
had come to China from the south and so did not come into contact with the
Wall.[115] Thus, Father [Martino Martini](/wiki/Martino_Martini "Martino
Martini")'s mistaken claim that the Wall had "lasted right up to the present
time without injury or destruction"[184] since the time of Qin was accepted as
fact by the 18th-century _[philosophes](/wiki/Philosophes
"Philosophes")_.[185]

Since then, many scholars have operated under the belief that the Great Wall
continually defended China's border against the steppe nomads for two thousand
years.[186] For example, the 18th-century sinologist [Joseph de
Guignes](/wiki/Joseph_de_Guignes "Joseph de Guignes") assigned
[macrohistorical](/wiki/Macrohistorical "Macrohistorical") importance to such
walls when he advanced the theory that the Qin construction forced the Xiongnu
to migrate west to Europe and, becoming known as the [Huns](/wiki/Huns
"Huns"), ultimately contributed to the [decline of the Roman
Empire](/wiki/Decline_of_the_Roman_Empire "Decline of the Roman Empire").[187]
Some have attempted to make general statements regarding Chinese society and
foreign policy based on the conception of a perennial Great Wall: [Karl
Marx](/wiki/Karl_Marx "Karl Marx") took the Wall to represent the stagnation
of the Chinese society and economy,[188] [Owen Lattimore](/wiki/Owen_Lattimore
"Owen Lattimore") supposed that the Great Wall demonstrated a need to divide
the nomadic way of life from the agricultural communities of China,[189] and
[John K. Fairbank](/wiki/John_K._Fairbank "John K. Fairbank") posited that the
Wall played a part in upholding the [Sinocentric](/wiki/Sinocentric
"Sinocentric") world order.[190]

Despite the significance that the Great Wall seemed to have, scholarly
treatment of the Wall itself remained scant during the 20th century. [Joseph
Needham](/wiki/Joseph_Needham "Joseph Needham") bemoaned this dearth when he
was compiling the section on walls for his _[Science and Civilisation in
China](/wiki/Science_and_Civilisation_in_China "Science and Civilisation in
China")_ : "There is no lack of travelers' description of the Great Wall, but
studies based on modern scholarship are few and far between, whether in
Chinese or Western languages."[191] In 1990, [Arthur
Waldron](/wiki/Arthur_Waldron "Arthur Waldron") published the influential _The
Great Wall: From History to Myth_ , where he challenged the notion of a
unitary Great Wall maintained since antiquity, dismissing it as a modern myth.
Waldron's approach prompted a re-examination of the Wall in Western
scholarship.[192] Still, as of 2008, there is not yet a full authoritative
text in any language that is devoted to the Great Wall.[193] The reason for
this, according to _[The New Yorker](/wiki/The_New_Yorker "The New Yorker")_
journalist [Peter Hessler](/wiki/Peter_Hessler "Peter Hessler"), is that the
Great Wall fits into neither the study of political institutions (favoured by
Chinese historians) nor the excavation of tombs (favoured by Chinese
archeologists).[194] Some of the void left by academia is being filled by
independent research from Great Wall enthusiasts such as
ex-[Xinhua](/wiki/Xinhua "Xinhua") reporter Cheng Dalin (成大林) and self-funded
scholar [David Spindler](/wiki/David_Spindler "David Spindler").[195]
